Dialogue:
CU: Hello!  
ED: Hello!  
CU: This summer was really hot, wasn't it?  
ED: Yes, it was very exhausting.  
CU: I went to an outdoor music festival last weekend and ended up with heatstroke.  
ED: Are you okay now?  
CU: After being in a place without shade for about five hours, I had a headache and nausea.  
ED: That must have been difficult.  
CU: Yes, I went to the infirmary by myself and felt better after resting for a while.  
ED: I'm glad you recovered. Was it during the daytime?  
CU: Yes, it was an event from morning until night, and I got tired during the day.  
ED: I see. The enthusiasm of the venue probably made it feel even hotter.  
CU: Yes, the crowd made it easy to forget about COVID-19. Did you go anywhere?  
ED: At the end of July, I went to Karuizawa.  
CU: Karuizawa? I've never been there. Is it really a nice place?  
ED: I thought it would be cool, but it was over 30 degrees.  
CU: Even Karuizawa is hot as expected. How did you spend your time?  
ED: There was my younger brother's wedding.  
CU: I see, congratulations. At which venue?  
ED: Thank you. It was at the Stone Church of Hoshino Resorts.  
CU: I know it! It's a beautiful chapel, isn't it?  
ED: Yes, it was very wonderful.  
CU: Since I was working in the bridal industry, I bet the food was delicious.  
ED: Yes, it was really delicious. I enjoyed it since I rarely go to Hoshino Resort.  
CU: I'm really jealous. I want to go there someday.  
ED: It was hotter than I expected, but it was a lovely place full of nature.  
CU: Since I live in the Kansai region, it's really difficult for me to go to Karuizawa.  
ED: I'm also from Kansai. It’s convenient to access from Tokyo.  
CU: So you're from Kansai too. It's easier to get there from Tokyo.  
ED: Yes. I made my way leisurely through Nagoya.

CU: Thank you in advance.
ED: You're welcome!
CU: Have you picked up any new hobbies recently?
ED: Yes, I've been really into jigsaw puzzles lately.
CU: That sounds like a lot of fun! Are you working on a large one right now?
ED: It's a 1000-piece puzzle, so it's not too big, but it's still challenging.
CU: I bet it's really engaging. You must get completely absorbed in it.
ED: Definitely, sometimes I even forget to take breaks for meals.
CU: Do you have many completed puzzles at home?
ED: Yes, I have quite a few. I stopped displaying them after a while because there were too many.
CU: I've always wondered what to do with a jigsaw puzzle once it's completed.
ED: Do you enjoy doing jigsaw puzzles too?
CU: I’ve done a few in the past.
ED: Deciding what to do with a finished puzzle can be tricky. Lately, I’ve been taking them apart and storing them.
CU: I see. Isn't it a bit disappointing to dismantle a completed puzzle?
ED: I only keep the ones that I really love on display.
CU: That makes sense. I might start working on a puzzle again soon!
ED: It's a great way to pass the time, especially in a comfortable environment.
CU: It sounds like a wonderful hobby!
ED: Thank you! What have you been into recently?
CU: I've recently gotten into K-pop groups.
ED: Like BTS?
CU: Yes! I like BTS, but my current favorite is their brother group, TXT.
ED: K-pop is incredibly popular. A friend of mine is really into it too.
CU: It's trending! There are so many videos on YouTube that I lose track of time watching them.
ED: There are even K-pop dance schools now.
CU: Yes, I've heard that some of the neighbor's children attend them.
ED: An acquaintance’s child goes there and is really good at dancing.
CU: That’s amazing! They have a bright future ahead.
ED: I agree. Wishing them the best!

CU: Good evening!
ED: Good evening!
CU: Do you have any pets?
ED: No, do you?
CU: Yes, I have a dog.
ED: What breed?
CU: Have you heard of a Cavalier?
ED: No, is it rare?
CU: Not really. Small to medium with floppy ears.
ED: I checked. Is it in 101 Dalmatians?
CU: Maybe. They shed a lot. It's challenging.
ED: How old?
CU: Six.
ED: That's quite old for a dog. Dogs are wonderful.
CU: What kind do you like?
ED: Big dogs and Shiba Inus.
CU: Big dogs are great but hard to keep.
ED: My cousin had a Husky. So cute!
CU: Huskies are friendly.
ED: Yes, affectionate despite looking like wolves.
CU: That’s charming.
ED: Yes, but they shed a lot in summer.
CU: July is the worst. Tough to manage.
ED: It must be challenging and hot.
CU: The Roomba fills up quickly.
ED: Pets are very comforting.
CU: Yes, they really are. Hope you get one someday.
ED: Work travel makes it hard.
CU: That's tough. Hope it works out for you.
ED: Yes, leaving them is hard.

CU: Hello!  
DN: Hello. How can I assist you today?  
CU: It's been another hot and humid day. I’m struggling with the heat.  
DN: The temperature is indeed high here too.  
CU: Were you out somewhere?  
DN: Yes, I was out for work today.  
CU: Is your work indoors?  
DN: Yes, I work in an air-conditioned environment.  
CU: I do too, but the heat outside is hard to handle.  
DN: Do you leave early in the morning?  
CU: No, I usually leave around 8 o’clock.  
DN: That time is generally cooler than later.  
CU: Yes. Last week I attended an outdoor festival and got heatstroke.  
DN: What festival was it?  
CU: Summer Sonic, a music festival. Have you heard of it?  
DN: No, I haven't.  
CU: Many famous artists participate.  
DN: Which artists were there?  
CU: Artists like Yuri and Motohiro Hata.  
DN: What kind of music do they play?  
CU: They play pop music. It was fun, but extremely hot.  
DN: Were you wearing a mask at the event?  
CU: Yes, although it wasn’t strictly enforced.  
DN: Managing the heat must have been difficult. Was it outdoors without cover?  
CU: Yes, it was under the sun. Umbrellas were prohibited, so I used a hat.  
DN: Did people collapse from the heat?  
CU: Yes, some did. The weather has been unusual.  
DN: Yes, it has. Did you have to stand the entire time?  
CU: I stood only for the artists I wanted to see. You should look it up if you get a chance.  
DN: Thank you for sharing. I'll look into it.

CU: Hello!  
DN: Hello. How can I assist you today?  
CU: Have you traveled anywhere recently?  
DN: I frequently visit the Kansai region on weekends.  
CU: That sounds interesting! Where do you go specifically?  
DN: Nishinomiya.  
CU: Any particular places you like there?  
DN: I study music and visit my son in Mita.  
CU: Is your work related to music?  
DN: No, but I'm aiming to become a musician.  
CU: That's cool! I play the piano myself.  
DN: I study the harpsichord.  
CU: The harpsichord has a lovely sound.  
DN: I enjoy playing Bach on it.  
CU: Do you have one at home?  
DN: Yes. What do you play on the piano?  
CU: I practice pieces by Chopin and Debussy.  
DN: They are challenging on the harpsichord.  
CU: I recently visited the Yamaha piano factory.  
DN: Shizuoka has many music-related places.  
CU: They had a harpsichord on display.  
DN: Was it large?  
CU: No, it was small.  
DN: Yamaha also showcases harpsichords.  
CU: Are they expensive?  
DN: A Kawai harpsichord is around 2 million yen.  
CU: That's about as much as a grand piano!  
DN: Yes, overseas ones can cost more.  
CU: Keep practicing!  
DN: Thank you. Good luck with your piano practice too!

CU: Good evening!
DN: Good evening. How can I assist you?
CU: Do you have dinner plans tonight?
DN: We will eat out tonight.
CU: Just the two of you?
DN: No, my college-aged son is home for the holidays, so the three of us will go out together.
CU: Do you know where you might go?
DN: Not yet, but it will be either shabu-shabu or yakiniku.
CU: Both are popular choices. Young people enjoy meat.
DN: Yes. I want my son to decide.
CU: Do you enjoy having your son visit?
DN: Yes, it’s reassuring to have him nearby.
CU: Sons often give their mothers peace of mind.
DN: Are your children living with you?
CU: Yes, they are in junior high school, so we are together. Thinking about them leaving someday makes me feel sad.
DN: That’s understandable. I used to be more independent, now I try to be less so.
CU: You must have been a strong mother.
DN: That was part of the problem. Seeing their weak mother, they feel they have to become strong.
CU: I see. I tend to be responsible too.
DN: Mothers often feel the need to be reliable for their sons.
CU: True, they think they have to raise strong children. But it can have the opposite effect.
DN: It seems so. A teacher said boys should value their pride.
CU: My mother-in-law says that too. She believes boys have high pride.
DN: Yes. For boys, pride is significant.
CU: Boys and girls are different.
DN: Yes. I need to show a bit of weakness.
CU: I understand. Since he's been reliable lately, I'll try to depend on him more.
DN: Yes. But if it's too much, it might be overwhelming.
CU: Balancing that is a process of trial and error.
DN: Yes. Keep trying.

CU: Good morning.

BH: Good morning! How can I assist you today?

CU: How’s the weather there?

BH: It’s getting cloudy. Rain might start soon.

CU: Same here. This summer was incredibly hot, wasn't it?

BH: It sure was. How did you cope with the heat?

CU: I prepared for an outdoor music festival.

BH: What kind of preparations did you make?

CU: Have you heard of the cooling gel ring that freezes at 28 degrees?

BH: No, can you explain it?

CU: It’s a gel ring you can wrap around your neck to stay cool.

BH: Did it work well?

CU: Yes, it lasted for about an hour and a half. Quite effective!

BH: I’ve used cooling towels before.

CU: Do they make your clothes wet?

BH: Sometimes, yes. My son’s clothes got soaked once.

CU: Did you take him somewhere special?

BH: Yes, we went to the hospital.

CU: Even short trips can make you sweat a lot.

BH: Absolutely. I change clothes after shopping.

CU: Doing laundry every day is really tough.

BH: I understand. It’s especially hard when it rains and the laundry is outside.

CU: We use a dryer to help with that.

BH: I do too, but some clothes can’t be dried that way.

CU: Like clothes that wrinkle easily?

BH: Yes, and printed clothes might get damaged.

CU: Printed clothes often stick together in the dryer.

BH: True, but the dryer is still very useful.

CU: It’s great when you’re in a hurry.

BH: Agreed, but towels don't stay fluffy.

CU: Hello!  
BH: Hello!  
CU: Do you have any favorite foods or dishes?  
BH: I like spicy food and shrimp, so dishes like shrimp with chili sauce are the best.  
CU: Ebi chili is delicious! I also enjoy spicy food and Korean cuisine.  
BH: Do you make it often?  
CU: Yes, I’ve been making it a lot recently.  
BH: What dishes do you make?  
CU: Samgyeopsal, chijimi, and tteokbokki. Do you know them?  
BH: I make Korean pancakes with pre-mixed flour sometimes.  
CU: I use pre-mixed flour for chijimi too. Tteokbokki comes from a kit.  
BH: Is it easy to make?  
CU: Yes, very easy! But it might be too spicy for kids.  
BH: My daughter loves spicy food.  
CU: She might really enjoy it then.  
BH: I'll look for it. Is it sold in supermarkets?  
CU: Yes, it's available in supermarkets now.  
BH: I'll check for it today.  
CU: Samgyeopsal is easy to make and popular with children, too.  
BH: Is it just grilling pork?  
CU: Yes, and making a sweet and spicy miso called samjang.  
BH: Is samjang sold in stores?  
CU: Yes, but you can also make it at home if you have gochujang.  
BH: I'll look into that.  
CU: Wrap the meat with seasoned bean sprouts, shredded green onions, and kimchi in lettuce or perilla leaves.  
BH: I might have Korean food tonight.  
CU: That sounds great, enjoy!  
BH: My son doesn't like spicy food.  
CU: Make a non-spicy ssamjang without gochujang.  
BH: Thank you!

CU: Thank you in advance.
BH: You're welcome.
CU: Have you picked up any hobbies or interests recently?
BH: I enjoy watching dramas.
CU: I watch a lot of dramas too! What are you currently watching?
BH: I'm enjoying "Unicorn" and "Sekiko to Haneo."
CU: Really? I'm watching those too! Also "Magic Renovation."
BH: Renovations are really inspiring.
CU: They are! The actors are so talented, don't you think?
BH: Yes, they are. Do you have a favorite actor?
CU: You like Tomoya Nakamura, right?
BH: Yes, Haneo. They perform very well.
CU: It's impressive how they can play so many roles.
BH: Yes, he is versatile.
CU: Who's your favorite actor?
BH: For "Ishiko and Haneo," I like Akaso-kun.
CU: Akaso-kun is great! I'm interested in him too.
BH: After seeing him in another drama, I watch everything he’s in.
CU: Me too! Which drama did you first notice him in?
BH: "Cherry Magic." It was a BL drama and wonderful.
CU: I missed that one! Wish I saw it.
BH: He co-starred with Keita Machida, and they were both impressive.
CU: That’s awesome! Mr. Machida is also in the Self-Defense Forces now, which is cool!
BH: Yes, it's cool. The drama's content was okay, but they made it watchable.
CU: Totally. The content felt a bit like a sports club, but their physical appeal was impressive.
BH: Was that fan service for women? There was quite a lot, which surprised me.
CU: Probably. It’s a bit embarrassing, but I’ll check it out.
BH: Watching it with family, I kept it moderate.
CU: That can be awkward. But watching dramas is a great way to take a break!
BH: Yes, taking breaks is important.

CU: Good morning.
FF: Good morning. How can I assist you today?
CU: It's hot again today. What's the weather like there?
FF: It’s somewhat sunny here, and there might be some rain.
CU: Is your area affected by the typhoon?
FF: No, I’m in the Kanto region. How about you?
CU: We're in Kansai, and the typhoon seems manageable.
FF: The typhoon is still around Kyushu. It’s best to stay updated.
CU: There has been a lot of abnormal weather lately.
FF: Yes, natural disasters are becoming quite frequent.
CU: The heat is also extreme.
FF: This year has been particularly hot. How are you coping?
CU: I had heatstroke recently. It was tough.
FF: Were you outside for a long time?
CU: Yes, at a music festival.
FF: Outdoor events in such heat can be risky.
CU: I was without shade for about five hours and got a severe headache.
FF: That’s tough. I hope you’re better now.
CU: I went to the first-aid room to rest.
FF: I’m glad you took care of yourself.
CU: I still managed to see the artist I wanted to.
FF: Which artist were you there for?
CU: A Korean idol group and One Ok Rock.
FF: ONE OK ROCK concerts are known to be exciting. How was it?
CU: One OK Rock was thrilling.
FF: Concerts can be a great way to relieve stress.
CU: Yes, they help me unwind sometimes.
FF: Managing stress is important. Take care.
CU: Yes, I will be more careful. Thank you.
FF: You’re welcome. Stay safe!
